Description:
The Reformation profoundly challenged traditional religious beliefs, and New World voyages and Eastern trade ventures exposed the English to varied and alien faiths.

This course will consider a selection of Shakespeare plays that reflect these dramatic developments, beginning with The Merchant of Venice and Hamlet.

 

Brief Bio

Richard McCoy is distinguished professor of English at Queens College and The Graduate Center, CUNY, and the author of Faith in Shakespeare (Oxford, 2013).
ShortDesc: The Reformation profoundly challenged traditional religious beliefs, and New World voyages and Eastern trade ventures exposed the English to varied and alien faiths.
Title: Coffee & Classics: Shakespeare and Religion

Description:
This seminar proposes to examine the phenomenon of Confessional poetry.

What did these four poets write about themselves that merits the rubric “Confessional?” Each poet lived in turmoil. Three of the four poets committed suicide. How did they lay bare their psyches in their poems? How do we as readers feel about listening to a recital of so much personal unhappiness? How do their conflicted lives get expressed in the styles and forms of their poems? Sexton and Plath were students of Lowell at Boston University and Berryman was a good friend of his. Do they comprise a school of poetry? And one last important question: the traditional lyric poem is a kind of self-communion and sometimes exposes raw nerves and psychological crises. How do the lyric poems of this quartet differ from a Shakespeare sonnet, one of Coleridge’s romantic meditation, “Frost at Midnight,” or Modernist poems saturated in angst? This class will attempt to answer the above questions. This class will focus on Lowell’s Life Studies, Berryman’s Dream Songs, Plath’s Ariel and a selection of Anne Sexton’s poems.

 

Brief Bio

Herbert Leibowitz is the founder and editor of Parnassus: Poetry in Review and the author of "Something Urgent I Have to Say To You": The Life and Works of William Carlos Williams.
ProdStatus: PASSED FIRST CLASS DATE
ShortDesc: This seminar proposes to examine the phenomenon of Confessional poetry.
Title: Reading Berryman, Lowell, Plath and Sexton with Herbert Leibowitz

Description:
The aging Lear fantasizes a semiretirement, letting his three daughters take over.

He sets a trap: Who shows most love earns the biggest slice. Slather me in sycophantic verbiage. The first two girls do a terrific job, but the youngest decides to tell her father the truth. All hell breaks loose. The old king ends up abandoned in a storm worthy of the damned on the back wall of the Sistine Chapel. And this is only part one!

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ProdStatus: PASSED FIRST CLASS DATE
ShortDesc: The aging Lear fantasizes a semiretirement, letting his three daughters take over.
Title: King Lear

Description:
“I sound my barbaric yawp over the rooftops of the world,” Walt Whitman announced in Leaves of Grass.

We'll commemorate the volume's 160th anniversary by closely reading it alongside much of his work, paying attention to his ability to “contain multitudes,” (both in life and language), his virtuosity, his generosity and his singular but dramatic influence on American letters.

 

Brief Bio

Brenda Wineapple is the award-winning author of White Heat, a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle award and Ecstatic Nation, a "beautifully written, artfully constructed, and passionately argued [...] narrative history,” writes Ron Chernow. She teaches at the New School and Columbia University.
ShortDesc: “I sound my barbaric yawp over the rooftops of the world,” Walt Whitman announced in Leaves of Grass, whose 160th anniversary we’ll commemorate by closely reading that volume and much of his work.
Title: Reading Whitman with Brenda Wineapple

Brief Bio

Description:
Every poem, short or long, has to turn toward its conclusion.

Some turn with advance notice; others come rushing in the last half of the last line, hair undone. We will read, then write, poems that pace their conclusions from explosion to whisper, from shock to reassurance.

Class meets: Feb 8, 22, Mar 1 and 8.

 

Brief Bio

ShortDesc: Every poem, short or long, has to turn toward its conclusion.
Title: The Magic of the Turn with Molly Peacock

Description:
Finnegans Wake is a hilarious and beautiful experiment.

Over four Sundays we will focus on several excerpts in an attempt to gain some understanding of Joyce’s work—and some joy in it. As the drinking song that inspired Joyce’s title puts it, there is “lots of fun at Finnegans Wake.”

“Crucial parts of my life are all intimately tied to Joyce, who writes the kind of work of art that rewards readers in different ways depending on the stage of life they are at, their backgrounds and interests, their talents as readers and their limitations – but does reward every reader who lets it do that,” writes instructor Michael Groden.

Our students say: “Dr. Groden gave us his prodigious knowledge along with such freshness and enthusiasm. He has opened a world of richness and stimulation and insight for me that has and will continue to enrich my life. The pleasures of reading Joyce seem more attainable and the challenges less difficult. I could not have wished for a better class.”

Class meets: Feb 8, 22, Mar 1 and 8.

 

Brief Bio

Scholar and critic Michael Groden is the author of Ulysses in Progress and the new Ulysses in Focus, general editor of The James Joyce Archive, a recipient of an honorary DLitt degree from University College Dublin and Distinguished University Professor of English at the University of Western Ontario.
ShortDesc: Finnegans Wake is a hilarious and beautiful experiment. Over four Sundays we will focus on several excerpts in an attempt to gain some understanding of Joyce’s work—and some joy in it.
Title: Reading Finnegans Wake with Michael Groden

Description:
Explore the surprising back-stories and timeless revelations of four of children’s literature’s best-loved tales: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, The Wind in the Willows, Peter Pan and The Secret Garden.

How did it happen that at a high moment of scientific discovery, nationalist fervor, and social transformation, a mathematician, a banker, a playwright and a romance writer all made their most enduring marks as authors of storybook fantasies for children? Who were their illustrators? Who were their critics? Why are their books still read more than a century later?

Class meets on Wednesdays: Feb 11 and 25 and Mar 11 and 25.

 

Brief Bio

Leonard S. Marcus is one of the children’s book world’s most respected writers, historians and critics. He is the author of books on Randolph Caldecott, Maurice Sendak and Madeline L’Engle, among others, as well as the curator of The ABC of It: Why Children’s Books Matter at the New York Public Library.
ShortDesc: Explore the surprising back-stories and timeless revelations of four of children’s literature’s best-loved tales: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, The Wind in the Willows, Peter Pan and The Secret Garden.
Title: Down the Rabbit Hole and Beyond: Four Childrens Classics Revisited With Leonard S. Marcus

Description:

It may be because of subject matter, language, pacing, plot or vocabulary. Don’t be discouraged; you’re not alone. Join us to read and analyze just such a book: Middlemarch, by George Eliot.
ShortDesc: The best of readers sometimes discover books that are either too long or too difficult to get through.
Title: Middlemarch by George Eliot

Description:
It’s the Trojan War. Seven years ago Troy’s Prince Paris snatched stunning Helen from her Greek husband. And the exhausting, spiteful conflagration drags on.

What a provocative setting for a love story, or maybe more properly stated, a lust story. Riverside Shakespeare says, “The modern theater has decided firmly, and rightly, that the play’s a brilliant scarifying vision of the world torn to pieces … its intellectualism, savagery and disillusion speak forcefully to contemporary audiences.” I think you will love it.

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ProdStatus:
Sold Out.

Waiting list available.
ShortDesc: It’s the Trojan War. Seven years ago Troy’s Prince Paris snatched stunning Helen from her Greek husband. And the exhausting, spiteful conflagration drags on.
Title: Troilus & Cressida

Description:
The older I wax the more I understand and admire this brilliant and emotionally complex masterwork.

It’s Shakespeare’s final tragedy and maybe his most 21st century thinking. Military prowess, fame and politics are exposed in this astonishingly graphic glare at private faces in public places. My favorite Shakespeare play. Wow!

The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”

Title: Coriolanus

Description:
“While in Rome...”

For our third play at “Friday Shakespeare,” we’ll tackle the wildly popular Julius Caesar. Private faces in public places! “Friends, Romans, Countrymen...” Here’s a play that many first encountered in high school. But, as with Coriolanus there’s a depth of examination of human character that rewards adult observation. Friendship, trust, ennobled objectives and human foibles are woven into the tapestry of this beloved tale of huge ego and ultimate destruction.

Title: Julius Caesar with Bob Smith

Description:
Hamlet’s the high water mark in Western literature.

For those also taking Troilus and Cressida on Wednesdays at noon, here’s what could be a superb juxtaposition! The play digs deep into fathers and mothers and sons and daughters. This time we’ll look through the prism of Hamlet’s disenchantment with his mother and his heart-breaking disentanglement from poor Ophelia. There isn’t a better play!  For those in both sessions, look for a dialogue between this well known classic and the awesome bitterness of the lesser known play, Troilus and Cressida.

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ShortDesc: Hamlet’s the high water mark in Western literature.
Title: Hamlet with Bob Smith

Description:
“All the world’s a stage...” No play could more perfectly launch this brand new Friday Shakespeare series with Bob Smith!

This well-loved masterwork is a manual for love and courtship, and no instructor could be more qualified than Shakespeare’s glorious Rosalind. Touchstone’s fooling, Orlando’s purity, vain Phoebe, worshipful Sylvius, sexy goat herd Audrey, and the world-weary Jaques people this phenomenally good-natured play. Is it an accident that Shakespeare set his romantic classroom in the bucolic forest of Arden [his mother’s maiden name]? “...Come, woo me, woo me; now I am in a holiday humor... ”

 

Brief Bio

Bob Smith has been teaching Shakespeare seminars at 92Y for over 20 years and is the author of Hamlet’s Dresser: A Memoir. The New York Times described Smith as, “Contagious...a plain spoken autodidact whose passion for Shakespeare regularly breaks attendance records...when Bob Smith twinkles at full throttle there’s star dust everywhere.” Library Journal dubbed him, “The teacher we all should’ve had to introduce us to Shakespeare.” The Boston Globe calls him, “Inspired and inspiring.” In Toronto The Globe and Mail found Bob, “Open, warm, funny, generous, spontaneous, thoughtful and entirely charming...it’s Smith’s ability to find the common humanity in even the most different of us that traces itself to his Shakespeare obsession.”
ShortDesc: “All the world’s a stage...” No play could more perfectly launch this brand new Friday Shakespeare series with Bob Smith!
Title: As You Like It with Bob Smith

Description:
“I long to embrace, to include in my own short life, all that is accessible to man. I long to speak, to read, to wield a hammer in a great factory, to keep watch at sea, to plow. I want to be walking […] in the open fields, or on the ocean—wherever my imagination ranges,” writes Anton Chekhov.

Chekhov is considered to be one of the world’s most popular playwrights. His tales—astute, economical and often humorous—are equally remarkable and influential. Join Liza Knapp, who returns to 92Y by popular demand, and read Chekhov’s tales with an eye to understanding how they explore the human condition.

 

Brief Bio

Liza Knapp teaches and writes about the Russian classics, both within the Russian context and in relation to their counterparts in English, French and American literature. She has served as the online “literary expert” for Oprah Winfrey’s Book Club and chairs the Slavic department at Columbia University.

A student writes: “Liza Knapp is hands down and far and away the best professor I encountered. Very knowledgeable, extremely patient and incredibly insightful. Even if you have read the material before, you will get a thousand times more out of it with her as your guide. Most importantly, she is truly excited about what she is teaching, and you can tell that she loves it.”
ShortDesc: “I long to embrace, to include in my own short life, all that is accessible to man. I long to speak, to read, to wield a hammer in a great factory, to keep watch at sea, to plow. I want to be walking … in the open fields, or on the ocean—wherever my imagination ranges,” writes Anton Chekhov.
Title: Readings Chekhovs Tales with Liza Knapp

Description:
The beauty of slow reading applies to drama as well as the novel.

In the spirit of recent revivals, this summer we will be examining deep themes within this four-act play.

Please bring a copy of Three Sisters by Chekhov.
ShortDesc: The beauty of slow reading applies to drama as well as the novel.
Title: Slow Reading: Three Sisters by Chekhov

Description:
From 1956 to 2002, Saul Bellow made regular appearances at 92Y. To celebrate his centenary, friends and fellow writers gather to read from his work. “The backbone of 20th-century American literature has been provided by two novelists—William Faulkner and Saul Bellow,” wrote Philip Roth. “Together they are the Melville, Hawthorne and Twain of the 20th century.”

 

This reading is endowed in memory of Ronald Busch.
ShortDesc: To celebrate Saul Bellow’s centenary, friends and fellow writers gather to read from his work.
Title: Saul Bellow at 100

Description:
Learn the basics of cartooning.

Develop your personal style while exploring a variety of forms from single gags to longer comic strips to storyboarding your graphic novel.

No drawing experience necessary.
ProdStatus:
Sold Out.

Waiting list available.
ShortDesc: Learn the basics of cartooning.
Title: Comic Storytelling

Description:
Each of us has a story to tell. But finding the words and voice to tell it with is an art and craft specific to each storyteller.

This course will concentrate on each student’s unique approach to telling his or her tale. Not for the shy or faint of heart.

 

Brief Bio

Oliver Trager has worked as an editor for 25 years and is the author of Dig Infinity! The Life and Art of Lord Buckley, Keys to the Rain: The Definitive Bob Dylan Encyclopedia and The American Book of the Dead: The Definitive Grateful Dead Encyclopedia.
ShortDesc: Each of us has a story to tell. But finding the words and voice to tell it with is an art and craft specific to each storyteller.
Title: How to Write Your Autobiography

Description:
Designed for those writing novels, this yearlong workshop offers extended sessions for intensive workshopping.

Students are expected to enroll for both semesters. Enrollment is limited to 10 students. Spring semester begins on Tue, Feb 10, from 6-9 pm.

Manuscript submission required

 

Brief Bio

Stephen Wright’s novels include Going Native, Meditations in Green and, most recently, The Amalgamation Polka, a novel that “speaks uncannily from within its period, in the tradition of heartbroken humor which America’s lapses of faith in its own promise have always evoked in the finest of our storytellers,” wrote Thomas Pynchon.
ShortDesc: Designed for those writing novels, this yearlong workshop offers extended sessions for intensive workshopping.
Title: Novel Writing with Stephen Wright

Description:
Designed for those composing a book-length manuscript of poetry, this yearlong workshop reviews and re-envisions works individually and collectively, close up and hands-on.

Students also consider a few exemplary, recently published collections of poetry. Passes to select Poetry Center readings will be made available to participating students. Enrollment is limited to 10 people. Please note that students must enroll for both semesters.

Manuscript Submission required

 

Brief Bio

Sophie Cabot Black is the author of The Misunderstanding of Nature, winner of the Norma Farber First Book Award; The Descent, winner of the Connecticut Book Award; and, most recently, The Exchange. Her honors include the Grolier Poetry Prize and the Poetry Society of America’s John Masefield Memorial Award.
ShortDesc: Designed for those composing a book-length manuscript of poetry, this yearlong workshop reviews and re-envisions works individually and collectively, close up and hands-on.
Title: Poetry Thesis with Sophie Cabot Black

Description:
At Seamus Heaney’s death in 2013, the canon of his published poems closed.

In this seminar, we’ll survey lyrics from Heaney’s first seven volumes (1966-96) preceding the 1995 Nobel Prize. We’ll follow his successive topics: childhood, youth, the sufferings of women, nationalism, the Northern Irish “troubles,” the move to pastoral Wicklow, marriage, and, increasingly, elegy. We’ll be led through the poems by the changes in Heaney’s style—from Keatsian richness to archaic terseness, from the phenomenal to the invisible, from gravity to “walking on air.”

A future seminar will take up Heaney’s last three books—Electric Light, District and Circle, and Human Chain—and will consider his life-long investigation of the possibilities of the long sequence.

 

Brief Bio

Helen Vendler is the A. Kingsley Porter University Professor at Harvard. Her most recent books are Dickinson: Selected Poems and Commentaries and Last Looks, Last Books: Stevens, Plath, Lowell, Bishop, Merrill. She is a frequent reviewer of poetry in such journals as The New York Review of Books, The New York Times Book Review and The New Republic.
ShortDesc: At Seamus Heaney’s death in 2013, the canon of his published poems closed. In this seminar, we’ll survey lyrics from Heaney’s first seven volumes (1966-96) preceding the 1995 Nobel Prize.
Title: Helen Vendler on Seamus Heaney

Description:
Study the art of fiction through readings and discussions of character, voice, point of view, story structure and other craft elements.

Create, develop and revise your own original stories through writing exercises, activities and feedback from a full-class workshop.

Manuscript submission required

 

Brief Bio

Justin Torres is the author of We the Animals, a national best-seller. A recipient of an NEA grant and a Cullman Center Fellowship from the NYPL, he has published fiction in The New Yorker, Harper's and Granta.
ProdStatus: PASSED FIRST CLASS DATE
ShortDesc: Study the art of fiction through readings and discussions of character, voice, point of view, story structure and other craft elements.
Title: Advanced Fiction with Justin Torres

Description:
Mary Ruefle is the author of Trances of the Blast; Madness, Rack, and Honey: Collected Lectures and The Most of It.

She is the recipient of an Award in Literature from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts and a Whiting Award. “Ruefle is clearly one of the best American poets writing, and her body of work is remarkable for its spiritual force, intelligence, stylistic virtuosity, and adventurousness," writes Tony Hoagland.

This advanced workshop meets in conjunction with Ruefle’s appearance in the Poetry Center’s Reading Series. Accepted students will receive complimentary passes to the reading. Applications must be received by Wednesday, November 19 at 5 pm. The work presented as the manuscript submission is also the work discussed in the master class.
ProdStatus: PASSED FIRST CLASS DATE
ShortDesc: Mary Ruefle is the author of Trances of the Blast; Madness, Rack, and Honey: Collected Lectures and The Most of It.
Title: Poetry with Mary Ruefle

Description:
Carolyn Forch is the author of Gathering the Tribes, which won the Yale Series of Younger Poets Prize, The Country Between Us and the forthcoming In the Lateness of the World.

Her famed international anthology, Against Forgetting, was praised by Nelson Mandela as "itself a blow against tyranny, against prejudice, against injustice.”

This advanced workshop meets in conjunction with Forch’s appearance in the Poetry Center’s Reading Series. Accepted students will receive complimentary passes to the reading. Applications must be received by Sunday, October 6 at 10 am. The work presented as the manuscript submission is also the work discussed in the master class.
ProdStatus: PASSED FIRST CLASS DATE
ShortDesc: Carolyn Forch is the author of Gathering the Tribes, which won the Yale Series of Younger Poets Prize, The Country Between Us and the forthcoming In the Lateness of the World.
Title: Poetry with Carolyn Forch

Description:
Fiction intensifies insight with discernment. It emphasizes the fleeting and barely perceptible. It allows us to see the unfamiliar in the everyday, and to gape at the new with recognition. 

This workshop focuses on developing students’ ability to think analytically about the form and content of their fiction.

Both traditional and more experimental and innovative elements of fiction will be considered.

Manuscript Submission Required

 

Brief Bio

Christopher Sorrentino is the author of Trance, a finalist for the National Book Award for Fiction, and the forthcoming The Fugitives. He writes for The New York Times, Esquire, Harper's and McSweeney's. “He possesses a searing gaze, a polymath’s erudition, and a lover’s ear for the frailties of human language,” writes Jonathan Lethem. Visit Brooklyn Rail to read his story “The Great Ape.”
PriorityRegMessage: Manuscript submission required. Please login to enroll if you have been accepted into this class.
ProdStatus:
NOT FOR SALE ONLINE.

Call Customer Service at 212.415.5500.
ShortDesc: This workshop focuses on developing students’ ability to think analytically about the form and content of their fiction.
Title: Advanced Fiction with Christopher Sorrentino

Description:
A workshop for writers of fiction for children and young adults.

The writing process is not just putting down one page after another—it's a lot of writing and then rewriting, restructuring the story, changing the way things come together.

In this class, we discuss published work and student writing, giving particular attention to voice, character, dialogue, interior monologue and world-building.

Manuscript Submission Required

 

Brief Bio

A 92Y Writing Program alumna, Rebecca Stead is the author of When You Reach Me, a winner of the Newbery Medal, and Liar & Spy, a New York Times Book Review Notable Book for Children. The Washington Post calls her work “incandescent.”
ProdStatus:
NOT FOR SALE ONLINE.

Call Customer Service at 212.415.5500.
ShortDesc: A workshop for writers of fiction for children and young adults.
Title: Advanced Fiction with Rebecca Stead

Description:
Over 8 weeks, students will examine key elements in fiction through close reading of their own writing and that of their peers, along with focused in-class exercises.

From our students: “Sandra Newman is an outstanding instructor. She’s attentive, patient, and responsive, both in the classroom and as editor, and led me to discover added dimensions in my work.”

Manuscript Submission Required

 

Brief Bio

Sandra Newman is the author of The Only Good Thing Anyone Has Ever Done, Changeling, and co-author of How Not to Write a Novel. “I can’t remember when I last read something so original or sophisticated or emotionally engaging or so breathtakingly ambitions,” writes Kate Atkinson about The Country of Ice Cream Star.
ProdStatus:
NOT FOR SALE ONLINE.

Call Customer Service at 212.415.5500.
ShortDesc: Over 8 weeks, students will examine key elements in fiction through close reading of their own writing and that of their peers, along with focused in-class exercises.
Title: Advanced Fiction with Sandra Newman

Description:
“Feel unique in roiling solitude? Oh, you are not alone / though you may feel fallen, snow up your nose. Join / with others in your dank reclusion,” writes Sharon Dolin in “A Manual for Living,” a series of self-help poems she has been writing even when she feels like she’s not writing poems.

This workshop is designed to challenge and expand the kinds of poetic strategies students bring to writing poems.

Those writing in traditional forms will be encouraged to incorporate more experimental techniques, such as chance and procedural operations, while experimental writers will be encouraged to explore traditional techniques, such as narrative and form, in theirs.

Manuscript Submission Required

 

Brief Bio

Sharon Dolin is the author of Burn and Dodge and Whirlwind, “a book of wonderful whimsy, grace and bite,” writes Terrance Hayes. She is writer-in-residence at Eugene Lang College and directs the Center for Book Arts Letterpress Poetry Chapbook Competition.
ProdStatus:
NOT FOR SALE ONLINE.

Call Customer Service at 212.415.5500.
ShortDesc: This workshop is designed to challenge and expand the kinds of poetic strategies students bring to writing poems.
Title: Advanced Poetry with Sharon Dolin

Description:
“I want you to fall asleep with your mouth open / so I can put something exquisite in it,” writes Jeanne Marie Beaumont in “What the Director Said.”

In this class, we will explore poetry as an art of communication, imagination and transformation.

In particular, we will critique student and model poems to examine aspects of innovation, control and revision. Our goal is, as Virginia Woolf says, to “let our nets down deeper and deeper and gently draw in ... and make poetry.”

Manuscript Submission Required

 

Brief Bio

Jeanne Marie Beaumont is author of Placebo Effects, Curious Conduct and Burning of the Three Fires. She teaches in the Stonecoast MFA Program at the University of Southern Maine. “Here is one great blessed eyeball encountering the world, no, colliding with it in endless cancellations, where to see, to think, and to imagine combine in one impulse to make a poetry of poetries,” writes Mary Ruefle about Beaumont’s work.
ProdStatus:
NOT FOR SALE ONLINE.

Call Customer Service at 212.415.5500.
ShortDesc: Expand your writing processes to explore poetry as an art of communication, imagination and transformation.
Title: Advanced Poetry with Jeanne Marie Beaumont

Description:
In this exclusive tutorial, each student will work with Schulman for 4 intense 30-minute one-on-one sessions.

The sessions will be scheduled at the first meeting on Feb 3, which is mandatory for all enrolled students. This class meets at the instructor’s home in Greenwich Village. Enrollment is limited to 7.

Manuscript Submission Required

 

Brief Bio

Grace Schulman is the author of Days of Wonder: New and Selected Poems, The Broken String and Without a Claim. She is a former director of the Unterberg Poetry Center, former poetry editor of The Nation and a distinguished professor of English at Baruch College. She is “not only a poet of praise, but one who addresses the grounding questions of this mode. How and why do we find beauty in adversity?,” writes Ron Slate.
ProdStatus:
NOT FOR SALE ONLINE.

Call Customer Service at 212.415.5500.
ShortDesc: In this exclusive tutorial, each student will work with Schulman for 4 intense 30-minute one-on-one sessions.
Title: Poetry Tutorial with Grace Schulman

Description:
“I found that the memoirist has to be honest and explore her own foibles and missed steps and acknowledge them and be humble,” writes Hettie Jones. “All of that I did just in my quest for the truth of the matter, or simply because I've always tried to be an honest person—to admit what it is I've done wrong. In that respect, the process was very healing for me.”

Students in this workshop begin to create a personal memoir in the context of its own time and place.

Guided by exercises and numerous examples from published material, each week students present for discussion a three-page response to the exercises. The result is a solid start to a larger work.

Manuscript Submission Required

 

Brief Bio

Hettie Jones is the author of the forthcoming Love, H: A Correspondence. Her memoir How I Became Hettie Jones is “a story that every American ought to read. The writing is easy, effortless, honest,” writes Jamaica Kincaid.
ProdStatus:
NOT FOR SALE ONLINE.

Call Customer Service at 212.415.5500.
ShortDesc: Students in this workshop begin to create a personal memoir in the context of its own time and place.
Title: Advanced Memoir Writing with Hettie Jones

Description:
“I am increasingly more interested in the idea of a poem being a dramatic lyric construct than I am in my poems being strictly autobiographical,” writes Sally Van Doren. “I like the challenge of making a poem sound confessional when it really is more of an imaginative excursion than a factual accounting of events.”

This course encourages students to generate new work both in and out of the classroom.

We look to each other and to other published poets for inspiration as we hone our poetic voices.

 

Brief Bio

Sally Van Doren is the author of Possessive and Sex at Noon Taxes, which received the Walt Whitman Award. Her “language is alive. The movement of language is alive. The mind at work here is at all points, quick, full of play and bite,” writes August Kleinzahler.
ShortDesc: This course encourages students to generate new work both in and out of the classroom.
Title: Poetry Writing with Sally Van Doren

Description:
This class will focus on the art of writing short fiction. We’ll read a range of contemporary stories, ask, “How did the author do this?” and then try, to the best of our abilities, to answer that question.

Alongside craft elements like characterization, story structure, point of view, and the balance between scene and summary, we’ll also discuss the challenges and rewards of process and practice. Weekly short writing exercises will help students explore particular aspects of fiction-making, and one longer story from each student, due toward the end of course, will be discussed in a supportive full-class workshop.

Students will be encouraged to expand their conception of short fiction, and to experiment, push, and transform their own storytelling in imaginative ways.

New dates: 2/16, 2/23, 3/2, 3/9, 3/16 and 3/23

 

Brief Bio

Anthony Tognazzini's recent work has appeared in Guernica, BOMB and Gigantic. His fiction collection, I Carry A Hammer in My Pocket for Occasions Such As These, was the inaugural book in their American Reader Series. He has received a residency from the Djerassi Resident Artists Program and awards from the Academy of American Poets, the Association of Writers and Writing Programs and the Greer Artist Foundation. He lives in Brooklyn with his wife, the poet Robin Beth Schaer, and their son Faro.
ShortDesc: This class will focus on the art of writing short fiction. We’ll read a range of contemporary stories, ask, “How did the author do this?” and then try, to the best of our abilities, to answer that question.
Title: Fiction Writing with Anthony Tognazzini

Description:
We write most authentically when we disarm ourselves of our notion of who we are and what we should write.

The subtitle of this workshop is: The Play You Did Not Intend to Write. In this workshop we will explore the possibilities of dramatic text and stage space through guided, short, idiosyncratic assignments. Writers will complete short pieces (6-12 pages in length) which can stand alone or start a train of thought towards a longer work. All levels of experience welcome.

 

Brief Bio

Anne Washburn's plays include The Internationalist, The Communist Dracula Pageant and Mr. Burns, which is currently running at Playwrights Horizons. “Mr. Burns. This intoxicating and sobering vision of an American future, set during a day-after-tomorrow apocalypse, isn't just some giddy head trip. It has depths of feeling to match its breadth of imagination,” writes Ben Brantley.
ProdStatus:
Sold Out.

Waiting list available.
ShortDesc: We write most authentically when we disarm ourselves of our notion of who we are and what we should write.
Title: Playwriting with Anne Washburn

Description:
“I sound my barbaric yawp over the rooftops of the world,” Walt Whitman announced in Leaves of Grass.

We'll commemorate the volume's 160th anniversary by closely reading it alongside much of his work, paying attention to his ability to “contain multitudes,” (both in life and language), his virtuosity, his generosity and his singular but dramatic influence on American letters.

 

Brief Bio

Brenda Wineapple is the award-winning author of White Heat, a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle award and Ecstatic Nation, a "beautifully written, artfully constructed, and passionately argued [...] narrative history,” writes Ron Chernow. She teaches at the New School and Columbia University.
ShortDesc: “I sound my barbaric yawp over the rooftops of the world,” Walt Whitman announced in Leaves of Grass, whose 160th anniversary we’ll commemorate by closely reading that volume and much of his work.
Title: Reading Whitman with Brenda Wineapple

Description:
Every poem, short or long, has to turn toward its conclusion.

Some turn with advance notice; others come rushing in the last half of the last line, hair undone. We will read, then write, poems that pace their conclusions from explosion to whisper, from shock to reassurance.

Class meets: Feb 8, 22, Mar 1 and 8.

 

Brief Bio

Molly Peacock is the author of The Paper Garden, How to Read a Poem and Start a Poetry Circle and The Second Blush. One of the creators of New York’s Poetry in Motion program, she serves as the series editor of The Best Canadian Poetry in English.
ShortDesc: Every poem, short or long, has to turn toward its conclusion.
Title: The Magic of the Turn with Molly Peacock

Description:
Finnegans Wake is a hilarious and beautiful experiment.

Over four Sundays we will focus on several excerpts in an attempt to gain some understanding of Joyce’s work—and some joy in it. As the drinking song that inspired Joyce’s title puts it, there is “lots of fun at Finnegans Wake.”

“Crucial parts of my life are all intimately tied to Joyce, who writes the kind of work of art that rewards readers in different ways depending on the stage of life they are at, their backgrounds and interests, their talents as readers and their limitations – but does reward every reader who lets it do that,” writes instructor Michael Groden.

Our students say: “Dr. Groden gave us his prodigious knowledge along with such freshness and enthusiasm. He has opened a world of richness and stimulation and insight for me that has and will continue to enrich my life. The pleasures of reading Joyce seem more attainable and the challenges less difficult. I could not have wished for a better class.”

Class meets: Feb 8, 22, Mar 1 and 8.

 

Brief Bio

Scholar and critic Michael Groden is the author of Ulysses in Progress and the new Ulysses in Focus, general editor of The James Joyce Archive, a recipient of an honorary DLitt degree from University College Dublin and Distinguished University Professor of English at the University of Western Ontario.
ShortDesc: Finnegans Wake is a hilarious and beautiful experiment. Over four Sundays we will focus on several excerpts in an attempt to gain some understanding of Joyce’s work—and some joy in it.
Title: Reading Finnegans Wake with Michael Groden

Description:
Explore the surprising back-stories and timeless revelations of four of children’s literature’s best-loved tales: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, The Wind in the Willows, Peter Pan and The Secret Garden.

How did it happen that at a high moment of scientific discovery, nationalist fervor, and social transformation, a mathematician, a banker, a playwright and a romance writer all made their most enduring marks as authors of storybook fantasies for children? Who were their illustrators? Who were their critics? Why are their books still read more than a century later?

Class meets on Wednesdays: Feb 11 and 25 and Mar 11 and 25.

 

Brief Bio

Leonard S. Marcus is one of the children’s book world’s most respected writers, historians and critics. He is the author of books on Randolph Caldecott, Maurice Sendak and Madeline L’Engle, among others, as well as the curator of The ABC of It: Why Children’s Books Matter at the New York Public Library.
ShortDesc: Explore the surprising back-stories and timeless revelations of four of children’s literature’s best-loved tales: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, The Wind in the Willows, Peter Pan and The Secret Garden.
Title: Down the Rabbit Hole and Beyond: Four Childrens Classics Revisited With Leonard S. Marcus

Description:
J. D. McClatchy is the author of Hazmat and Mercury Dressing, which won the Ambassador Book Award.

He has received numerous commendations for his work, including the Award in Literature from the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters and fellowships from the Guggenheim and the National Endowment for the Arts and a Literary Lion commendation from the New York Public Library. He is editor of the Yale Review.

Applications must be received by Mon, Mar 9 at 5 pm. Work presented as the manuscript submission will be shared among accepted students and discussed in this exclusive three-hour workshop.

Submitted manuscripts must consist of 6 pages of poetry, no more than one poem per page.

Enrollment is limited to six students.
ProdStatus:
NOT FOR SALE ONLINE.

Call Customer Service at 212.415.5500.
ShortDesc: J.D. McClatchy is the author of Hazmat and Mercury Dressing, which won the Ambassador Book Award.
Title: Master Class: Poetry with J. D. McClatchy

Description:
Allan Gurganus is the author of Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All, for which he won the Sue Kaufman Prize from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, White People, for which he won the Los Angeles Times Book Prize, and Local Souls.

His honors include a fellowship from the Guggenheim Foundation and membership in the American Academy of Arts and Letters.

Applications must be received by Mon, Mar 9 at 5 pm. Work presented as the manuscript submission will be shared among accepted students and discussed in this exclusive three-hour workshop.

Submitted manuscripts must consist of 15 pages of prose, double-spaced.

Enrollment is limited to six students.
ProdStatus:

Start with a personal experience, generate a compelling narrative, color it in, get coached on how to tell it effectively, and then perform it for your friends and family in a final class showing. This class will include guest talks by some of NYC’s best live storytellers, and will be fun, intense, illuminating—and change the way you tell stories forever.

Description:
Forget free verse, you’ve no excuse, come learn to rhyme like Dr. Seuss!

Do you reflexively string words together when you walk? Do you like a tight Scrabble game? Do you wince at rap’s and free verse’s “near-rhymes?” Then this course is for you! We address rhythm, rising/falling meter, scansion and all kinds of rhymes. For newbies and veteran word-clangers alike. If you've read to the end of this rant and you buy it, risk rhyming! (You know that you’re dying to try it…)
ShortDesc: Forget free verse, you’ve no excuse, come learn to rhyme like Dr. Seuss!

Description:
The smell cinnamon rolls baking the oven; the texture of a well-worn coat; the reprise of a certain once-loved song—the sensory details of everyday experience can add richness and spark to what we write.

Using delightful sensory prompts, Laura will show you how to tap into your best material, enriching memory and story with imagery and detail. All levels.

 

Brief Bio

Laura Deutsch is a writer, editor and teacher based in Mill Valley, California. Her book, Writing from the Senses, was published by Shambhala in 2014. Laura began teaching writing in 1974 at the University of California at Berkeley and has subsequently taught classes and workshops at San Francisco State University, Book Passage bookstore, Tassajara Zen Mountain Center, Green Gulch Farm Zen Center and in Arezzo, Italy. For the past fifteen years, her classes have focused on personal essay and memoir, writing from the senses, writing as a spiritual practice and how to get into print. Laura's personal essays, feature stories and travel pieces have appeared in the Los Angeles Times, the San Francisco Chronicle, San Francisco magazine, More magazine, Time Out, Mademoiselle and the Dallas Morning News. Her personal essays have been anthologized in several collections, including I Should Have Stayed Home; Best Women's Travel Writing 2011; and Leave the Lipstick, Take the Iguana. Her commentary has aired on public radio.
ShortDesc: The smell cinnamon rolls baking the oven; the texture of a well-worn coat; the reprise of a certain once-loved song—the sensory details of everyday experience can add richness and spark to what we write.
Title: Writing from the Senses

Description:
Hey writers and artists: is your style quirky and independent?

Straightforward and accessible? Spare and gritty? Are you more interested in expressing your emotions, or in describing visceral action? Focus on workshop activities and short-term projects to set the groundwork for more developed narratives that will help you acquire a working knowledge and arrive at your particular style.
ShortDesc: Hey writers and artists: is your style quirky and independent?

Step back in time to relive the old days in this enchanting bus tour!

Take a trip through the timeless brownstone neighborhoods of Brooklyn Heights and Park Slope, then, visit Ebbets Field, where the Brooklyn Dodgers played as well as Victorian Flatbush. View Brooklyn movie locations including The Godfather, Dog Day Afternoon, Sophie’s Choice, Moonstruck and more! Top off the afternoon with a stop at the world-famous Junior’s on Flatbush Avenue.

This tour is approximately 4 ½ hours long.

 

Meet at Union Square in Manhattan on the corner of East 13th Street and Fourth Avenue in front of the Blimpie’s Sandwich Shop. Please arrive by 10:15 am; bus leaves promptly at 10:30 am. Transportation and food included.

Description:
Despite communications technologies and today’s interlocked international markets, the world has never been more stratified.

Countries have different perceptions of the times and misunderstand each others’ politics, cultures and institutions. Is globalization just a superficial construct? Is reality like a science-fiction time-warp—in which major countries and regions simultaneously exist in the 21st, 19th and 7th centuries? Join this fascinating on-going discussion.

 

Brief Bio

Edward Goldberg is an expert on globalization and how geo-economic/political events shape our lives. He is an adjunct professor at Baruch College’s Zicklin Graduate School of Business and is also on the adjunct faculty of the New York University Center for Global Affairs, where he teaches international political economy.
ShortDesc: Despite communications technologies and today’s interlocked international markets, the world has never been more stratified.
Title: Is Globalization Dead?

Increase your awareness and understanding of timely, thought-provoking foreign policy issues involving the US. Each week another thematic/geographic issue is placed in its historical content.

 

Brief Bio

Description:
Examine the historical development of the United States constitution.

Topics covered include the Constitutional Convention of 1787 and the relationship between the various branches of government. How did political, social and ideological change affect the structure, function and content of this supreme law of the land?

 

Brief Bio

James Coll is an adjunct professor of American and Constitutional history at Nassau Community college, an NYPD detective and the founder of ChangeNYS, a nonprofit organization formed to educate New Yorkers abut the need for nonpartisan civic and political reform in the state.
ShortDesc: Examine the historical development of the United States constitution.
Title: Understanding the Constitution

Description:
The assassination of JFK 50 years ago this past November was a defining moment in American history.

Yet the story of how his untimely death led to a change in the US Constitution is less well known. Examine constitutional provisions dealing with a premature vacancy in the presidency and legal changes over time in the order of presidential succession.

 

Brief Bio

James Coll is an adjunct professor of American and Constitutional history at Nassau Community college, an NYPD detective and the founder of ChangeNYS, a nonprofit organization formed to educate New Yorkers abut the need for nonpartisan civic and political reform in the state.

Title: How the JFK Assassination Changed the Constitution

Description:
Italy is home to Europe’s oldest Jewish community, dating to 200 BCE, in ancient Rome.

Discover Italy’s cucina ebraica (“Hebrew kitchen”) and desserts like sour cherry cheesecake from Rome’s famed Forno del Ghetto. Learn the stories behind many alla giudia (“Jewish way”) dishes, like fried artichokes and goose salami, as you enjoy a virtual tour of Italy’s many historic Jewish sights: the original ghetto erected in Venice in 1516; Rome’s Jewish Heritage Museum; Florence’s Moorish-style synagogue, built in 1882; and Pitigliano, a hilltop Tuscan town nicknamed “Little Jerusalem.”

Talk includes a tasting of classic Italian Jewish dishes.
ShortDesc: Italy is home to Europe’s oldest Jewish community, dating to 200 BCE, in ancient Rome.
Title: Jewish Italy: Food, Culture and Travel

Description:

You’ll meet “peat” and appreciate the important role it plays in the production process. You’ll even get a crash course on Gaelic pronunciations so you can confidently order your favorite dram. The class includes samplings of six whiskeys.

 

Brief Bio

Tommy Tardie is the owner and operator of The Flatiron Room in New York City and has been featured on Bloomberg, Fox News, The Robb Report, Wealth Magazine, Modern Luxury and Business Insider, among other outlets.
ShortDesc: The Flatiron Room’s Tommy Tardie gives you a true understanding of whiskey.

Description:
What goes on inside the minds of men? What do they really think about dating, relationships and sex?

Get answers straight from the source! Love coach Rachel DeAlto hosts a fun, hilarious and informative panel of six men who are ready for ALL of your questions. Nothing will be held back. Want to know what turns a man off? Why he didn’t call you back? How men really feel when you make the first move? Join us for cocktails and candid conversation.

 

Brief Bio

Rachel DeAlto is a communication and relationship expert, love coach, matchmaker and the author of the bestseller, Flirt Fearlessly. Rachel is dedicated to helping people remove the blocks that are holding them back in life and love. Rachel is passionate about building confidence and helping others to create healthy relationships. She developed her communications expertise through her undergraduate degree from the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University and later as a practicing trial attorney after receiving her Juris Doctorate at Seton Hall University School of Law.

Rachel has been featured on a multitude of media outlets including: "GMA," "The TODAY Show," CNN/HLN, "Access Hollywood," "The Steve Harvey Show," Fox News, Cosmopolitan and Glamour. Rachel is also a frequent TEDx speaker.

Developed by Ken Page, LCSW, longtime dating workshop leader at 92Y and author of the acclaimed book Deeper Dating, this is a dating event you can participate in from the privacy of your home. Using a unique online platform, you will learn about some of the most exciting, research-backed insights about finding love, and then you’ll meet and interact with new single people through directed, stimulating and inspiring conversations—all online! This event is for single men and women ages 25-45.

Description:
Join Actors Studio member Michael Carleton to learn the Stanislavski technique, or Method acting.

Participants will learn how to create a character, actor-preparation techniques and how to perform solo or with other actors. This is a wonderful class for anyone interested in learning for the first time or improving upon their skills. Topics covered include relaxation techniques, improvisation, script interpretation, sense memory and more.

 

Brief Bio

Michael Carleton is an actor/director/writer with over 30 years professional experience. He is a lifetime member of the Actors Studio, and recently returned from several years teaching acting and improvisation in Paris. Formerly he was the Producing Artistic Director of the Baltimore Shakespeare Festival, and the Artistic Director of Cape May Stage in New Jersey. His play, Every Christmas Story Ever Told! has had over 450 productions around the world, and another script, Hyde, in the Shadows was a Barrymore Award nominee for outstanding new play.

 

Image provided by Shutterstock.
ShortDesc: Join Actors Studio member Michael Carleton to learn the Stanislavski technique, or Method acting.
Title: Acting for Beginners

Description:
Our third series features more of the major stars of the 1950s, all in rarely seen Technicolor double features.

  • Broken Lance (1954) / The Badlanders (1956)
    Cattle Baron Spencer Tracy in the ferocious family saga with Jean Peters, Richard Widmark and Katy Jurado … plus Alan Ladd, Ernest Borgnine and Jurado in Delmer Daves' top western remake of The Asphalt Jungle.
  • Saddle The Wind (1958) … Dawn At Socorro (1954)
    Robert Taylor, Julie London and John Cassavetes as warring ranchers, scripted by Rod Serling … plus cardsharp Rory Calhoun and saloon gal Piper Laurie take on bad guys David Brian and Lee Van Cleef.
  • Pillars Of The Sky (1956) / Backlash (1956)
    Cavalry sergeant Jeff Chandler vs. Apache chief Michael Ansara, with Dorothy Malone and Ward Bond … plus director John Sturges pilots Richard Widmark and frontier widow Donna Reed in a top revenge western.
  • Ride Clear of Diablo (1954) / The Outriders (1950)
    Railroad detective Audie Murphy after his family’s killer (Dan Duryea), aided by Susan Cabor and Abbe Lane…plus Joel McCrea's a wagon train driver with Arlene Dahl, James Whitmore and Barry Sullivan.
  • Back To God’s Country (1953) / Black Horse Canyon (1954)
    Fur trader Rock Hudson and his wife (Marcia Henderson) pursued by sled through wolves, avalanches and Steve Cochran’s gang … plus Joel McCrea taming Diamond, the outlaw stallion and sultry Mari Blanchard.
  • Seven Men From Now (1956) / Gun Fury (1953)
    Ex-lawman Randolph Scott after Wells Fargo thief Lee Marvin in Budd Boetticher’s oater with Gail Russell … plus Civil War vet Rock Hudson in Raoul Walsh’s sleek drama with Donna Reed and Lee Marvin, originally shot in 3-D.
 

Brief Bio

Kurt Brokaw is Associate Teaching Professor at The New School and senior film critic of The Independent magazine (Independent-Magazine.org).
ShortDesc: Our third series features more of the major stars of the 1950s, all in rarely seen Technicolor double features.
Title: Lost Westerns III

Create five minutes of strong stand-up comedy material, then try it out at a major NYC comedy club.

Description:
Audrey Totter and Robert Montgomery in Lady in the Lake (1947)

Join our 12th consecutive year of rarely seen 1940s and 50s crime dramas. Discuss the stars, directors, novelists and pulp stylists.

  • Introduction
    Scenes from Each Dawn I Die, Who Done It?, Mask of Demitrios, Deadline at Dawn, Red Light, Secret Beyond the Door, The Strange Affair of Uncle Harry, Asphalt Jungle, Female Jungle, Breaking Point, Riot In Cell Block 11, Rise and Fall of Legs Diamond, Anatomy of a Murder, Pretty Poison, Someone to Watch Over Me.
  • Lady in the Lake (1944)
    Audrey Totter opposite Robert Montgomery’s private eye Philip Marlowe, in the subjective camera noir by Raymond Chandler.
  • The Great Gatsby (1949)
    Alan Ladd is F. Scott Fitzgerald’s enigmatic Gatsby in the original (rarely seen) crime fable with Betty Field, Shelley Winters, Ruth Hussey.
  • Detour (1945) and Detour (1992) 
    The quintessential bargain-basement killer pickup (Ann Savage, Tom Neal), plus the lost 90s remake with Tom Neal, Jr!
  • The Dark Mirror (1946) and A Stolen Life (1946)
    Which twin is the killer? Olivia de Havilland (opposite Lew Ayres) and Bette Davis (opposite Glenn Ford).
  • Roadhouse (1948) 
    Ida Lupino is the backwoods Upper Peninsula songbird with Cornel Wilde, Celeste Holm, crazy Richard Widmark in this encore favorite.
  • The Asphalt Jungle (1950)
    John Huston pilots noir’s best heist with Sterling Hayden, James Whitmore, Sam Jaffe, Louis Calhern and trampy Marilyn Monroe.
  • The Chase (1966)
    Arthur Penn’s neo-noir is the savage Southern stew from Horton Foote’s ungentle novel. Marlon Brando, Jane Fonda, Robert Redford, Janice Rule.
 

Brief Bio

Kurt Brokaw is Associate Teaching Professor at The New School and senior film critic of The Independent magazine (Independent-Magazine.org).
ShortDesc: Join our 12th consecutive year of rarely seen 1940s and 50s crime dramas. Discuss the stars, directors, novelists and pulp stylists.
Title: Killer Movies XII: Lost Films Noir

Description:
Wendy Wasserstein’s The Heidi Chronicles portrayed the trials, challenges, rewards and angst of single women in mid-twentieth century American life, with a remarkable dose of humor that won it both a Tony Award and the Pulitzer Prize.

Tony Vellela conducted exclusive video interviews with every original cast member, including Joan Allen, Boyd Gaines, Peter Friedman, Martha Plimpton and Cynthia Nixon, as well as Ms. Wasserstein. He presents an exploration of this landmark play, with clips from his interviews. A rare event for anyone who loves theater, recalls that society-changing era or is eager to learn about it!

Price includes lunch.

 

Brief Bio

He wrote and produced the PBS series “Character Studies.”

Description:
Why is it that ballet genius George Balanchine could legitimately claim to be the first “choreographer” of a Broadway musical?

This class evaluates Balanchine’s influence on Broadway dance by illuminating what happened when he ushered ballet onto the Broadway stage and situated it alongside vernacular dancing in such shows as On Your Toes, Babes in Arms, The Boys from Syracuse and Where’s Charley?

 

Brief Bio

Lisa Jo Sagolla, EdD, is the author of The Girl Who Fell Down: A Biography of Joan McCracken and Rock ‘n’ Roll Dances of the 1950s. A choreographer, critic, arts journalist and historian, she teaches at Columbia University.

Description:
“Tragedy is when I cut my finger; comedy is when you walk into a sewer and die,” Mel Brooks memorably said.

What is it about other people getting hurt that we find so funny? Humor expert David Misch (whose screenwriting credits include “Mork and Mindy” and “SNL”) explores the endless delights of physical comedy as exemplified by giants like Monty Python, Will Ferrell, Melissa McCarthy—and especially Buster Keaton, the grandfather of them all. By seeing the relationship between humor, the human appetite and our capacity for suffering, we see how comedy helps us giggle past the graveyard.

 

Brief Bio

David Misch is an author (Funny: The Book / Everything You Always Wanted To Know About Comedy), screenwriter (“Mork and Mindy,” “Saturday Night Live,” The Muppets Take Manhattan), teacher (his own courses on comedy at USC and musical satire at UCLA) and lecturer (Columbia University, Oxford University, the University of Sydney, the American Film Institute, New York Public Library). His play Occupied is in development at the Skylight Theatre in Los Angeles. More at www.davidmisch.com.
ShortDesc: “Tragedy is when I cut my finger; comedy is when you walk into a sewer and die,” Mel Brooks memorably said.
Title: Oucha! Why Pain Is Hilariousif its Someone Elses

Description:
Working with the legendary musical-theater writing team Rodgers & Hammerstein on the landmark Oklahoma!, the experimental Allegro and the beloved Carousel, choreographer Agnes de Mille revolutionized dance in the Broadway musical.

This class reveals how the artistic, business and personal interactions among the three creative artists sparked monumental changes in the creation and performance of Broadway choreography.

 

Brief Bio

Lisa Jo Sagolla, EdD, is the author of The Girl Who Fell Down: A Biography of Joan McCracken and Rock ‘n’ Roll Dances of the 1950s. A choreographer, critic, arts journalist and historian, she teaches at Columbia University.

Title: Rodgers & Hammerstein and Agnes de Mille: Revolutionizing Broadway Dance

Description:
In the postwar ’40s 20th Century Fox emerged as a studio of style and message.

Its producers and directors shaped the film noir genre, challenged social mores in witty comedies, tackled topical issues with daring frankness and found room to charm us with captivating fantasies. See some of the memorable films of that decade, with an emphasis on the styles of the directors that gave Fox its distinction. 

  • Feb 4: Fallen Angel (1945)
    Directed by Otto Preminger the year after Laura put him on the map and starring Dana Andrews, Linda Darnell and Alice Faye (in a rare dramatic role), this film more than holds its own as a classic noir about the power of love to redeem down-and-outer Andrews, who becomes trapped in a web of small-town murder.
  • Feb 11: The Ghost and Mrs. Muir (1947)
    Directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz and starring Gene Tierney, Rex Harrison, George Sanders and a young Natalie Wood. One of the most romantic fantasies Hollywood made, it’s charm only increases with the passage of time.
  • Feb 18: Kiss of Death (1947)
    Directed by Henry Hathaway and starring Victor Mature, Colleen Gray and Richard Widmark in his acclaimed film debut as psychopath Tommy Udo. A great noir, Hathaway’s film about ex-con Mature attempting to stay straight in the face of danger helped define the Fox noir style.
  • Feb 25: Gentleman's Agreement (1947)
    Directed by Elia Kazan and starring Gregory Peck, Dorothy McGuire, John Garfield and Celeste Holm. Trenchant topical filmmaking in its day, Laura Z. Hobson’s famous novel about middle-class antisemitism illustrates all that is lasting and dated in the “problem” film that Darryl Zanuck was committed to producing.
  • Mar 4: Unfaithfully Yours (1948)
    Written and directed by Preston Sturges and starring Rex Harrison, Linda Darnell, Rudy Valle and Barbara Lawrence. Harrison’s orchestra conductor (modeled after Sir Thomas Beecham) suspects his wife Darnell of infidelity to the tune of several musical pieces he conducts. Of course, there is no proof of her unfaithfulness, but Sturges winks at us as we scratch our heads and wonder.
  • Mar 11: I Was a Male War Bride (1949)
    Directed by Howard Hawks and starring Cary Grant and Ann Sheridan. The Hawksian woman always tries to fit in by proving her professionalism, by becoming “one of the boys.” Here, Hawks inverts his own principle as military man Grant tries to satisfy an arcane requirement to be married to Sheridan. Only hilarity can ensue!
  • Mar 18: A Letter to Three Wives (1949)
    Directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz and starring Linda Darnell, Jeanne Crain, Ann Sothern, Kirk Douglas, Paul Douglas and Jeffrey Lynn. One of the great postwar social comedies shows the conflicts of suburban life, changing gender roles and career aspirations—all within a cluster of female friends who receive a letter from an absent fourth declaring that she intends to run off with one of their husbands. Literate and witty, Mankiewicz won his first pair of Oscars for writing and directing this film.
  • Mar 25: All About Eve (1950)
    Directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz and starring Bette Davis, Anne Baxter, Gary Merrill, Celeste Holm, Hugh Marlowe and Thelma Ritter. The granddaddy of all backstage theatre stories, complete with the intrigues and betrayals that follow, this film restored Davis to the top of the heap and gave her one of her iconic roles as Margo Channing. Mankiewicz repeated his Oscar-winning feat of the previous year with this classic film.
 

Brief Bio

Andrew Dickos is the author of Street with No Name: A History of the Classic American Film Noir and Intrepid Laughter: Preston Sturges and the Movies. His third book, Abraham Polonsky: Interviews, came out last winter from the University Press of Mississippi.
ShortDesc: In the postwar ’40s 20th Century Fox emerged as a studio of style and message.
Title: Classic Hollywood Studio Style: 20th Century Fox in the 1940s

Description:
For over half a century, Orson Welles had a major impact on all aspects of the entertainment world: Theatre, Radio, Film and Television.

He was called "Boy Genius", as director of the Mercury Theatre, and a Radio Actor and Director, during the 1930's. From the notoriety of "War Of The Worlds," to his film directorial debut with Citizen Kane, Orson Welles was a force in the arts. Film Historian Philip Harwood presents this centennial appreciation of Orson Welles, through rare recordings, film, documentary and television footage. We will learn that there were different sides to Orson Welles.

 

Brief Bio

Film historian Philip Harwood teaches at Long Island University, C. W. Post Campus and Queens College.

Description:
Learn how to decorate and design your space to fit your budget, meet all your requirements and aesthetically represent your personality.

 

Brief Bio

Leonard Braunschweiger is a graduate of both New York University, where he received his BFA degree, and Parsons School of Design, where he had been a member of the faculty for over 20 years. He started his early career working for I.M. Pei and Partners where he designed interiors for the Dallas City Hall and other large scale projects. While in Europe he worked with architects and designers on restoration of historic buildings. The firm of Leonard Braunschweiger & Company Inc. was founded in 1983. At the time he was working in collaboration with the Gruzen Partnership on the Montana, a 36 story residential building. Leonard Braunschweiger was part of the committee for the New York League of Cerebral House Tours and has also exhibited his work on the tour. The firm has been published in numerous magazines including Interior Design, Area Magazine, New York Spaces and was the featured designer in an issue of New York Living. Leonard has also contributed work for book publications including Kitchen and Bath Design for Living, Bedrooms and Private Spaces, Color Detail and Design, Bathrooms and The Decorative Carpet.

Description:
Compassion is the most talked about and rapidly developing topic in psychology and neuroscience.

You can discover it for yourself in this eight-week Stanford course. Using the latest research in neuroscience and psychology, lectures, readings, exercises, meditation and class discussion, students in the course will learn to have self-compassion for themselves and a more composed and compassionate attitude to the challenges of everyday life.

This one of a kind course was created by Stanford neuroscientists, psychologists and contemplative scholars at Stanford Medical School's Center for Compassion and Altruism Research and Education. The class takes a secular, scientific approach to compassion and includes both an academic component and learning by doing and trying it out yourself. After becoming one of the most popular classes at Stanford University, it is now taught at Columbia University and Mt. Sinai School of Medicine in New York City.

For more on the research and benefits of the class, please see Program Notes.

 

Brief Bio

Elizabeth Pyjov teaches Compassion Cultivation Training at Columbia University and the Tibet House, and next semester she will offer her class here at 92Y. She has also taught workshops about compassion at NYU Medical School, and the Harvard Club of New York, where she leads a special-interest group about compassion. Elizabeth was born in Moscow, Russia, and grew up in the San Francisco Bay Area. She graduated from Harvard magna cum laude, with a degree in Romance Languages and Literatures and the Classics. She has worked for Global Justice in New York City, for Italian television at RAI International in Rome, at the United Nations in Geneva, and at the Stanford Center for Compassion and Altruism Research and Education at Stanford, CA. Elizabeth is fluent in Russian, French, Italian, Spanish and English. She has traveled around the world and has worked or studied in Argentina, Italy, France, Peru, Switzerland and Russia. Her international experience has led her to understand that among those of various traditions, customs and religions, people still find happiness in many of the same ways. They want to be healthy, do meaningful work and be close to their loved ones, and what is always helpful is kindness, a caring attitude and compassion. Elizabeth studied the neuroscience, philosophy and pedagogy of compassion at Stanford Medical School while working for CCARE. She is currently the Editor-in-Chief of Stanford’s Compassion Journal.
ShortDesc: Using the latest research in neuroscience and psychology, readings, practical exercises, meditation thought experiments and class discussion, develop a more composed and compassionate response to the challenges of everyday life.
Title: Stanford Compassion Cultivation Training

Lois Akner is the author of How to Survive the Loss of a Parent.

Description:
Entering a new stage of life? Feeling lost or scared? Facing a new phase, whether it’s one you’ve chosen or one that’s been thrust upon you, can be unsettling.

In this interactive session, learn powerful concepts and steps to help you move through life’s challenges and changes with a clearer sense of direction and greater confidence.
ShortDesc: In this interactive session, learn powerful concepts and steps to help you move through life’s challenges and changes with a clearer sense of direction and greater confidence.

Description:
Social media can be a powerful networking tool in today’s competitive marketplace.

But are you confused by the many available tools and how to use them? In this interactive workshop, learn the secrets for using LinkedIn, the most widely tapped business social network, to generate and build relationships with contacts, and understand how and when to use Facebook, Twitter and other social media to help land the perfect job.

Amy-Louise Goldberg is a certified Executive Coach in private practice and Career Coach at NYU. She received an MBA from Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management and has delivered workshops at both global industry conferences and local venues.

Do you wonder if, when and how you should bring up salary in the interview process?

Are you unsure about whether or not to negotiate for the most lucrative job offer? In this lively, interactive workshop, we cover secrets to bargaining and negotiating successfully, so that you get what you deserve and establish a strong employee-employer relationship. Brief Bio

Amy-Louise Goldberg is a certified Executive Coach in private practice and Career Coach at NYU. She received an MBA from Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management and has delivered workshops at both global industry conferences and local venues.

Description:
As a midcareer professional, you’ve likely acquired substantial experience and taken steps to grow within your chosen field.

The focus of this workshop is taking this success to the next level—through getting promoted, working more effectively with younger employees or embarking on a search for a more fulfilling role or even a fresh career. Join us for an interactive session in which we address your questions about succeeding in today’s competitive workplace.

 

Brief Bio

Amy-Louise Goldberg is a certified Executive Coach in private practice and Career Coach at NYU. She received an MBA from Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management and has delivered workshops at both global industry conferences and local venues.

With such talents as James Earl Jones and Linda Hunt doing voiceovers, you might think breaking into this field is impossible. Not so!

Learn an exciting method for beating the competition.

 

Brief Bio

Alan Schwartz has more than 11 years experience as a voice-over artist. He has done national commercial campaigns and is the voice of the Mac Operating System, iTunes and the iPod Shuffle.

Description:
This class offers the opportunity to integrate your losses into your life, weaving a journey of healing and reconciliation into your life.

An exceptionally moving workshop, where discussion, support, journaling and more will be incorporated without judgment and with the acknowledgement that there is no time frame for mourning.

 

Brief Bio

Cindy Barg, MEd, LMHC, is an intuitive licensed psychotherapist and a highly respected consultant, public speaker and author.

Description:
Are you your own worst enemy?

Negative selftalk can drain energy and block us from living to our full potential. Just as bad: Our inner critic often affects how we relate to others, resulting  in a lack of harmony, connection and understanding. In this introductory program, learn techniques that can help you embrace the positive intent of your inner critic and gain greater clarity about what matters to you most.

 

Brief Bio

Dian Killian, Ph.D., is a Certified Trainer with the international Center for Nonviolent Communication (CNVC), founder and former director of The Center for Collaborative Communication, and President now of Work Collaboratively, LLC. She is also co-author of Connecting Across Differences: A Guide to Compassionate, Nonviolent Communication and Urban Empathy: True Life Adventures of Compassion on the Streets of NY and a certified life coach.
ShortDesc: Are you your own worst enemy?

Description:
At 80 million strong, Generation-Y millennials are beginning to move into leadership positions in corporations, government and their own businesses.

Join Lindsey Pollack, the nation’s number-one Google-ranked “Gen-Y career expert” and author of the Becoming the Boss, and Dan Coates, president and co-founder of Ypulse, the leading authority on millennials, for an insightful discussion about how to navigate this enormous demographic shift—whether you’re a millennial on the rise or you work with one!

 

Brief Bios

Lindsey Pollak is a keynote speaker, corporate consultant and one of the country's leading experts on the Millennial Generation. She currently serves as an official Ambassador for LinkedIn, Spokesperson for The Hartford's "My Tomorrow" campaign and Chair of Cosmopolitan magazine's Millennial Advisory Board. Her speaking and consulting clients have included Barclays, Citi, GE, PwC, Ralph Lauren, Time Inc., Verizon, Yale, Harvard, Princeton, MIT and over 150 other organizations. Lindsey's advice and opinions have been featured in such media outlets as "The Today Show," The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, CNN and NPR. Forbes named her blog one of the 100 Best Websites for Your Career. Lindsey is a graduate of Yale University and is based in New York City.

Dan Coates is president and co-founder of Ypulse, the leading authority on Millennials. Ypulse’s intelligence is derived from SurveyU.com, an online research community of more than 150,000 Millennials and Thumb, a mobile social Q&A network where two million Millennials go to ask and answer each other’s questions. Ypulse leverages these tools to help those who market to and work with youth—and who wish to reach them in an authentic manner.

 

This event is part of the Young Professionals series.
ShortDesc: At 80 million strong, Generation-Y millennials are beginning to move into leadership positions in corporations, government and their own businesses.
Title: Becoming the Boss: New Rules for the Next Generation of Leaders

Description:
Good communicators are like healthy eaters.

We all know that consuming fewer calories each day can lead to a healthier life, but did you know that using fewer words makes you more productive? By simplifying the way we communicate, we can shorten meetings, reduce email and reclaim precious downtime in our overscheduled days. Emmy® Award-winning correspondent and communication coach Bill McGowan shares strategies for getting your message across with pitch-perfect communication.

 

Brief Bio

Bill McGowan is the coach of some of the biggest names in business and entertainment, including Sheryl Sandberg, Eli Manning, Kelly Clarkson, Jack Welch, Thomas Keller and Kenneth Cole, and is a trusted advisor in the C-suites of companies like Facebook, Deutsche Bank, Campbell’s Soup, L'Oreal and Burberry.

 

This event is part of the Young Professionals series.

Description:
Learn strategies for making a powerful first impression with a highly effective, clearly written and informative resume.

Get advice on how to articulate your value to prospective employers and show you can meet their needs. Get an insider’s view on what to avoid to ensure you get into the “yes” pile!

 

Brief Bio

Alyssa Gelbard is an expert career consultant and the Founder and President of Resume Strategists, a leading career consulting/personal branding firm. Alyssa’s personalized, strategic approach has been enabling clients to confidently market themselves in an increasingly competitive job environment for 14 years. She works with clients to identify their value and provides career strategies, results-oriented supporting materials (resume, cover letter and LinkedIn profile) and job search, networking and interviewing guidance to help them achieve their professional goals.

She is a recurring featured speaker on career development (resumes, interviewing and communications skills) at NYU’s Center for Career Development and has been an alumni interviewer for prospective students for almost 20 years as part of the Tufts University Admissions Program. Alyssa has also been a mentor and speaker at the non-profit Dress for Success, providing career and professional development guidance.

Staying current on the job market and career development trends is a priority for Alyssa, and as such, she belongs to numerous networks including NY Women in Communications, Ellevate, Tufts University Alumni Admissions Program, Tufts University Career Network, NYU SternConnect, American Marketing Association and the Public Relations Society of America.

Alyssa holds an MBA in Marketing from NYU’s Stern School of Business and a BA in Sociology from Tufts University.
ShortDesc: Learn strategies for making a powerful first impression with a highly effective, clearly written and informative resume.
Title: Resume Primer

Brief Bio

Carleen von Eikh is a former lecturing instructor at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, New York. Carleen founded Graceful Service Training to offer instruction in grace at the table, from customer service to dining etiquette.

Description:
Have you ever reached an impasse with colleagues, clients, a family member or person on the street?

Have you sought a solution that was more satisfying, effective and empowering, but felt unable to take the next step? Using curiosity to understand the needs—and actions—of others can be the first step towards developing your effective response.

In this interactive session participants will learn how to navigate challenging conversations by practicing a four-step communication model that transforms critical communication barriers into opportunities for clarity, collaboration and action.
MobileDesc: How do you respond to difficult situations and people while ensuring that your needs are met in ways you won’t regret?
ShortDesc: How do you respond to difficult situations and people while ensuring that your needs are met in ways you won’t regret?
