Description:
Sometimes it’s hard to hear a no.

And a no can take various forms, from our colleagues voting down an idea at work to our partners saying, “Not tonight,” to our kids acting out. In this interactive workshop learn some simple steps to help you hear what others are saying yes to when they say no, and find win-win solutions in which every-one’s needs matter. Come with some actual situations you’d like greater clarity on.

 

Brief Bio

Dian Killian, Ph.D., is a Certified Trainer with the international Center for Nonviolent Communication (CNVC), founder and former director of The Center for Collaborative Communication, and President now of Work Collaboratively, LLC. She is also co-author of Connecting Across Differences: A Guide to Compassionate, Nonviolent Communication and Urban Empathy: True Life Adventures of Compassion on the Streets of NY and a certified life coach.
ShortDesc: Sometimes it’s hard to hear a no.
Title: Hearing the Yes Behind the No: Getting What You Want Without Regretting it Later!

Description:
What goes on inside the minds of men? What do they really think about dating, relationships and sex?

Get answers straight from the source! Love coach Rachel DeAlto hosts a fun, hilarious and informative panel of six men who are ready for ALL of your questions. Nothing will be held back. Want to know what turns a man off? Why he didn’t call you back? How men really feel when you make the first move? Join us for cocktails and candid conversation.

 

Brief Bio

Rachel DeAlto is a communication and relationship expert, love coach, matchmaker and the author of the bestseller, Flirt Fearlessly. Rachel is dedicated to helping people remove the blocks that are holding them back in life and love. Rachel is passionate about building confidence and helping others to create healthy relationships. She developed her communications expertise through her undergraduate degree from the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University and later as a practicing trial attorney after receiving her Juris Doctorate at Seton Hall University School of Law.

Rachel has been featured on a multitude of media outlets including: "GMA," "The TODAY Show," CNN/HLN, "Access Hollywood," "The Steve Harvey Show," Fox News, Cosmopolitan and Glamour. Rachel is also a frequent TEDx speaker.

Join noted psychotherapist and author of Deeper Dating, Ken Page LCSW as he busts the myths that keep us searching for love—but rarely finding it. Discover a groundbreaking approach to dating based on the real skills of intimacy; not games, gimmicks or manipulation. Stay after for a wine reception and book signing following the event, where you can meet other participants and discuss these exciting ideas.

Developed by Ken Page, LCSW, longtime dating workshop leader at 92Y and author of the acclaimed book Deeper Dating, this is a dating event you can participate in from the privacy of your home. Using a unique online platform, you will learn about some of the most exciting, research-backed insights about finding love, and then you’ll meet and interact with new single people through directed, stimulating and inspiring conversations—all online! Olga Sahraoui is a flower designer and the founder and creative director of Jardin Majorele Flowers (jardinmajorele.com) in NJ and NYC. Olga earned a master’s in visual communication and linguistics and an associate’s degree in event planning.

Step up to the next level of bridge!

This class emphasizes a convention called Two-over-One (2/1), used in modern-day bridge which makes it easier to get to your games and slams. We also concentrate on play of the hand and defense, and review the conventions that you already know.

POKERprimaDIVAS™ helps women learn and win through poker, a hobby that can improve business skills, challenge the mind and boost confidence.

Plus, it's great fun! Learn the basics and participate in a tournament, and receive a free copy of PokerWoman.

 

Brief Bio

Ellen Leikind, an executive with Fortune 500 companies, developed PokerDIVAS to teach women to sharpen their strategic and analytical professional skills. She is the author of PokerWoman: How to Win in Love, Life, and Business using the Principles of Poker.

Description:
Maximize the potential of your iPhone and learn all the hidden features you may not have known about.

We’ll go over the basic operations in the first class, including using the phone, storing contacts, navigating email, web browsing and downloading apps. In the second session we will move on to more advanced features, such as customizing your settings, using the camera, notifications, battery-saving tricks and more. Before the class make sure to update your device with the latest operating system, and be sure to have your Apple ID set up and know your password.

Image provided by Shutterstock.
ShortDesc: Maximize the potential of your iPhone and learn all the hidden features you may not have known about.

Description:
Are you inspired by all the creative crafts you see on Pinterest, Instagram and craft blogs?

Unleash your creative side in this cool crafting class! Explore decoupage, collage, stamping, papier-mch, clay work, painting and more. Each week, we’ll break down a new technique for you, bringing a project from raw materials to finished product. All materials provided.

 

The Craft Studio has been a staple in the lives of New York City kids since founder Barbara Dansker opened its doors in 1994. In 2009, Lindsey Peers, who began working at The Craft Studio when she was just 19 years old, took over the business. 92Y is thrilled to be partnering with our neighbors to help adults unlock their creativity with crafts—why should kids have all the fun?
ShortDesc: Are you inspired by all the creative crafts you see on Pinterest, Instagram and craft blogs?

Class structured for students who have some knowledge of the game and are ready to go on to the next level.

We will review the basics and move on to the conventions that follow. The art of defense and play of the hand will also be included. Notes and materials are included.

Learn how to pick hands, gain confidence and play to win!

 

Subscribe and Save! These events can be purchased together as part of the following subscription: Mah-Jongg Supervised Play.

Description:
Why buy a preassembled florist bouquet when you can easily create a unique one of your own?

In this fun, hands-on floral workshop, learn some basic techniques to create beautiful arrangements. Explore the use of color blending and mechanics. Walk away with a beautiful self made floral arrangement that is sure to make mom smile. All flowers and materials are included.

 

Brief Bio

Olga Sahraoui is a flower designer, founder and creative director of Jardin Majorele Flowers in NJ & NYC. Olga earned her Masters in visual communication and linguistics, as well as Associate Degree in event planning. She took also couple of years apprenticeship in flower designs, working and mastering her skills with Michael Gaffney, Oliver Giugni and some upscale New York floral boutiques. She naturally developed an eye for details and artistic flower combinations.

Her recent clients are Neiman Marcus, Liberty House, Tory Burch Foundation and variety of corporate offices in NYC & NJ; Tony Award nominee Stephanie J. Block and actors of "House of Cards."

Her creative flair and stylistic approach allows her constantly to invent fresh and imaginative ways to incorporate flowers into special celebrations.
ShortDesc: Why buy a preassembled florist bouquet when you can easily create a unique one of your own?

Description:
Journey into the exotic world of mah jongg.

Inspired by the museum exhibition Project Mah Jongg, Ann Israel took mah jongg lessons with a group of friends, including Gregg Swain, the co-author of her recent book, Mah Jongg: The Art of the Game. When they started playing, they also began to appreciate the spectacular vintage sets that still existed, and soon Israel purchased her first. As Israel and Swain continued to collect vintage sets, each piece added to their appreciation of the art of the game. Join Israel as she shares images and stories of the most exquisite and rare mah jongg sets and ephemera.
ShortDesc: Journey into the exotic world of mah jongg.
Title: Mah-Jongg: The Art of the Game

Description:
James Andrew Miller Photo Credit: Victoria Wills

Hear the inside story of how the game of Monopoly came into existence, the heavy embellishment of its provenance by Parker Brothers and multiple media outlets, the lost female originator of the game, and one man’s lifelong obsession to tell the true story about the game’s questionable origins, from The Monopolists author Mary Pilon, as she also illuminates the cutthroat nature of American business over the last century.

 

Brief Bios

Mary Pilon is an award-winning sports reporter at The New York Times. She was previously a staff reporter at the Wall Street Journal for the paper’s Money and Investing section. In 2011, she was named one of Forbes magazine’s 30 Under 30 for media. Her work has appeared at Gawker, USA Today and New York magazine and she is an honors graduate of New York University.

James Andrew Miller is an award-winning journalist and #1 New York Times bestselling author. He got his start as a member of the Television Reporting Team at The Washington Post before becoming Special Assistant and Chief Speechwriter to then Senate Majority Leader Howard Baker. He was Vice President of Television for Norman Lear’s ACT III Communications, Executive Vice President of Original Programming for USA Network, producer with CBS News and Senior Executive Producer of "Anderson Cooper 360" & "Paula Zahn Now" at CNN. He is the author of Running In Place: Inside the Senate and co-author of Live From New York: An Uncensored History Of Saturday Night Live and Those Guys Have All The Fun: Inside the World of ESPN. He has written for The Washington Post, The New York Times, Newsweek, Grantland, The Daily Beast, Salon, The Harvard Journal on Legislation and others.
MobileDesc: Hear the inside story of how the game of Monopoly came into existence, the heavy embellishment of its provenance by Parker Brothers and multiple media outlets, the lost female originator of the game, and one man’s lifelong obsession to tell the true story about the game’s questionable origins, from The Monopolists author Mary Pilon, as she also illuminates the cutthroat nature of American business over the last century.
ShortDesc: Hear the inside story of how the game of Monopoly came into existence.
Title: The Monopolists: Obsession, Fury and the Scandal Behind Americas Favorite Board Game

Description:
The commuter day is so hectic, that few New Yorkers rushing through Grand Central ever really get to learn about the hidden history and lesser known lore behind this classic landmark.

Here's your chance as we celebrate Grand Central with a discussion of the symbolism behind its decor and the mysteries behind this Beaux Arts gem. Stops include Grand Central's "whispering arch"; Vanderbilt Hall; a secret apartment used as a speakeasy during the 1920s; JM Hewlett’s classic ceiling mural with its mysterious constellations painted in reverse; and Jules Coutan’s Roman group god sculpture—a crowning masterpiece to the structure.

This tour ends at 1 pm.

 

Meet in front of the entrance to the Oyster Bar on lower level of Grand Central. Subway: 4,5,6,7 to Grand Central.

Description:
Terror once reigned in the streets of New York.

Once war was declared, NYC industries grew rapidly to meet the demands of the Union war effort. Learn about Abraham Lincoln, Horace Greeley, the Confederate plot to burn the city and the terrible draft riots.

This tour is 1.5 hours long.

Description:
Join us on a walk across the "Great Bridge"—once the longest suspension bridge in the world—as we learn about its creation and early history.

We'll discuss the work of the Roebling family, the designers of the bridge, and the sacrifice and dramatic story of the immigrant workers who built it. We'll hear about Stephen Brody, the only person originally credited with jumping off the bridge—and living to tell about it, and PT Barnum, whose spectacular theatrics instilled confidence in New Yorkers to cross the span. We end at the Brooklyn Promenade to view the magnificent Manhattan skyline at twilight—only steps from Grimaldi's Pizza, the Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory, The River Cafe and the restaurants and cafes of Montague Street.

This tour is approximately 2 hours long.

 

Meet at the statue of Ben Franklin at Spruce St and Park Row in Lower Manhattan in front of Pace University. Subway: 4,5,6 to Brooklyn Bridge/City Hall. Subway: 4,5,6 to Brooklyn Bridge/City Hall.

John Ahearn Double Dutch 1981/2010; enamel and pigmented resin on fiberglass, overall: 79 1/2 x 142 1/2 x 9 1/2 in/202 x 362 x 24 cm; Photo: Joerg Lohse, Image courtesy Alexander and Bonin, New York

Artist John Ahearn talks with Cathie Behrend about his collaborative projects with Rigoberto Torres.

Description:
Join Ken Chaya, artist, urban naturalist, and creator of the celebrated tree map, “Central Park Entire,” for some unique nature walks in Central Park.

Discover obscure footpaths and architectural features, spot resident and migrant birds (bring binoculars!), learn about the many species of trees in bloom, and learn how to identify and appreciate nature right in the middle of NYC. Signed maps will be available at a discount price for all attendees.

In the early spring walk, trees will be opening their flowers and leaf buds; crocuses, irises and snowdrops will be among the first wildflowers to appear; early migrant birds will be passing through; and after a long winter of dormancy, fresh colors and textures will be emerging everywhere.

 

Brief Bio

Ken Chaya is a New York City artist, designer and urban naturalist. He spent over two and half years walking every acre of Central Park in order to map its many trails, highlight its stunning architecture and landscape features, and most importantly, locate and identify thousands of its magnificent trees. The result was “Central Park Entire,” a profusely illustrated map detailing the park’s varied topography and featuring the location and identification of nearly 20,000 trees and shrubs.
ShortDesc: Join Ken Chaya, artist, urban naturalist and creator of the celebrated tree map, Central Park Entire, for unique nature walks in Central Park.
Title: Central Park Nature Walks with Ken Chaya: Early Spring in Bloom

Brief Bio

Ken Chaya is a New York City artist, designer and urban naturalist. He spent over two and half years walking every acre of Central Park in order to map its many trails, highlight its stunning architecture and landscape features, and most importantly, locate and identify thousands of its magnificent trees. The result was “Central Park Entire,” a profusely illustrated map detailing the park’s varied topography and featuring the location and identification of nearly 20,000 trees and shrubs.
ShortDesc: Join Ken Chaya, artist, urban naturalist, and creator of the celebrated tree map, “Central Park Entire,” for some unique nature walks in Central Park.
Title: Central Park Nature Walks with Ken Chaya: Earth Day Bounty

Description:
Highlights include the site of the first synagogue in North America, the 18th-century Jewish ghetto, George Washington’s letter affirming tolerance toward Jews, and Peter Minuit Plaza, the flagpole inscription of which honors the original 23 Jews who came to Manhattan in 1654.

 

Meet at the steps of the Museum of American Indian – 1 Bowling Green, New York, NY 10004, south side of Bowling Green.
ShortDesc: Highlights include the site of the first synagogue in North America, the 18th-century Jewish ghetto, George Washington’s letter affirming tolerance toward Jews, and Peter Minuit Plaza, the flagpole inscription of which honors the original 23 Jews who came to Manhattan in 1654.
Title: Jewish Colonial Manhattan

Description:
Travel back in time to the 19th Century as we discover some of the lesser known sites from this stage of New York’s past.

Join us as we stroll past such hidden treasures as The Players Club, the residences of Theodore Roosevelt and 1876 presidential candidate Samuel Tilden; a stop on the Underground Railroad; the homes of John Barrymore and James Cagney; The Flatiron Building, New York’s first skyscraper; the Metropolitan Life Tower, once the World’s tallest; the site of the original Madison Square Garden, where architect Stamford White met his end; and the only intersection in the city with a prominent New Yorker buried beneath it!

 

Meet on the northeast corner of 21st St and Lexington Avenue under the plaque to Cyrus Field. Subway: N,R,6 to 23rd St.

Title: Madison Square and Gramercy Park

Description:
In the Uprising of the 20,000, remarkable women—from factory workers to aristocrats—left their imprint on this neighborhood and beyond.

Tour highlights include iconoclasts of literature, art and theater; the salon of Mable Dodge, a center of WWI-era activism; and the tragic Triangle Shirtwaist fire and its role in the labor and suffrage movements.
ShortDesc: In the Uprising of the 20,000, remarkable women—from factory workers to aristocrats—left their imprint on this neighborhood and beyond.
Title: The Radical, Notorious Immigrant Women of Washington Square

Description:
Take a refreshing ride across New York Bay and a stroll through the historic St. George area, including a 9/11 memorial, a baseball stadium and the restored St. George Theatre.

Please note that there are steep hills on this tour.

 

Brief Bio

Gordon Linzner is an urban historian.
ShortDesc: Take a refreshing ride across New York Bay and a stroll through the historic St. George area, including a 9/11 memorial, a baseball stadium and the restored St. George Theatre.
Title: Staten Island Ferry / St. George

Description:
Have you ever tasted potatonik?

Join the Lower East Side Jewish Conservancy for a stimulating stroll of the neighborhood, featuring delicacies based on original European recipes. Nosh on a fresh baked bialy, a pickle right out of the barrel, and potatonik. Historic Jewish sites include the Bialystoker Synagogue, a shteibl and Beth Hamedrash Hagadol.
ShortDesc: Have you ever tasted potatonik? Join the Lower East Side Jewish Conservancy for a stimulating stroll of the neighborhood, featuring delicacies based on original European recipes.
Title: Nosh and Stroll on the Lower East Side

Description:
For Lower East Side Eastern European immigrants and their children, the Upper East Side became a desired location of second settlement, offering better tenements, more space and small, charming apartment houses with modern amenities.

Urban historian Barry Feldman leads you past the Beaux Arts mansions of the Fifth Avenue “Gold Coast” and farther east.
ShortDesc: For Lower East Side Eastern European immigrants and their children, the Upper East Side became a desired location of second settlement, offering better tenements, more space and small, charming apartment houses with modern amenities.
Title: Were Movin On Up to the (Jewish) East Side: A Walking Tour

Description: Stops include FDR and Eleanor’s first NYC dwelling, where JFK worshipped and stayed during presidential trips to NY, the childhood home and baptismal site of Jacqueline Kennedy, the residence where FDR and Eleanor were married, the place where RFK revived his political career, the townhouse where Eleanor Roosevelt endorsed JFK, and the site of Teddy Roosevelt’s house.
ShortDesc: Stops include FDR and Eleanor’s first NYC dwelling, where JFK worshipped and stayed during presidential trips to NY, the childhood home and baptismal site of Jacqueline Kennedy, the residence where FDR and Eleanor were married and more.
Title: Roosevelts and Kennedys Walking Tour

Description:
The tour starts in Lower Manhattan, where Abraham Lincoln spoke as a candidate and as a president.

Visit sites and hear stories associated with his unpopularity in New York (he received only 34% of the city’s vote in 1864), like the location of the bloody Draft Riots. Cross over the Brooklyn Bridge to learn about the birthplace of the Union's ironclad Monitor and much more.
ShortDesc: The tour starts in Lower Manhattan, where Abraham Lincoln spoke as a candidate and as a president.
Title: Abraham Lincoln's New York

Description:
42nd Street is arguably the world’s most famous street.

Join us as we explore the great structures that put it on the map. Stops include the Chrysler Building, Grand Central, the New York Public Library, Times Square, the New Amsterdam Theatre, the birthplace of Eugene O’Neill and the Paramount Theatre, where Sinatra and the Beatles made girls swoon.
ShortDesc: 42nd Street is arguably the world’s most famous street.
Title: 42nd Street and Midtown

Description:
Discover the Village, the authors who lived there and what inspired them.

Stops include the death site of Thomas Paine and the homes of Mark Twain, Henry James, Edgar Allan Poe, Edith Wharton, Edward Albee, E. E. Cummings, Emma Lazarus, Edna St. Vincent Millay and John Reed.
ShortDesc: Discover the Village, the authors who lived there and what inspired them.
Title: Literary Greenwich Village

Description: Stops include the site of the notorious Five Points, made famous in Gangs of New York; the Brooklyn Bridge; the grave of Ireland’s most famous Revolutionary War hero; the Irish Hunger Memorial; Newspaper Row; and locations associated with the bloody Civil War Draft Riots, New York’s first Irish mayor and the Fenian movement.
ShortDesc: Stops include the site of the notorious Five Points, made famous in Gangs of New York; the Brooklyn Bridge; the grave of Ireland’s most famous Revolutionary War hero; the Irish Hunger Memorial; Newspaper Row; and more.
Title: Early Irish Manhattan

Description:
Stops include Plymouth Church, Warren Place, the Promenade, the site of Washington’s Cobble Hill brigade, the birth-place of Winston Churchill’s mother and the homes of writers Thomas Wolfe, Arthur Miller and Truman Capote.

Along the way sample some of the area’s classic and contemporary noshings, from Brooklyn egg creams to spinach pie and baklava.
ShortDesc: Stops include Plymouth Church, Warren Place, the Promenade, the site of Washington’s Cobble Hill brigade, the birth-place of Winston Churchill’s mother and the homes of writers Thomas Wolfe, Arthur Miller and Truman Capote.
Title: Brooklyn Heights & Cobble Hill Tasting Tour

Description:
This National Historic Landmark, the final resting place of some half a million people, is one of the city’s finest representations of Victorian life.

In the 19th century, it was America’s most popular tourist attraction other than Niagara Falls. Past the stunning brownstone entry gates designed by Gothic master Richard Upjohn are four lakes, a charming cathedral, ornate mausoleums, beautiful statuary, and Civil War and American Revolution monuments, as well as the graves of such luminaries as Leonard Bernstein, Horace Greeley and Samuel Morse.

Meet in front of the brownstone entry gates at Fifth Avenue and 25th Street.

 

Brief Bio

Adrienne Onofri is a journalist and licensed NYC sightseeing guide. She is the author of Walking Brooklyn.
MobileDesc:
This National Historic Landmark, the final resting place of some half a million people, is one of the city’s finest representations of Victorian life.

Meet in front of the brownstone entry gates at Fifth Avenue and 25th Street.
ShortDesc: This National Historic Landmark, the final resting place of some half a million people, is one of the city’s finest representations of Victorian life.
Title: Walking Brookyn: Green-Wood Cemetery

Description:
Get to know the two historic yet up-and-coming neighborhoods at the cultural heart of Brooklyn.

As if their proximity to the Brooklyn Museum, Botanic Garden, Central Library and Prospect Park weren’t enough, “ProCro” also offers block after block of classic rowhouses; smaller, uniquely themed museums; landmark districts and the hub of NYC’s West Indian population.

 

Brief Bio

Adrienne Onofri is a journalist and licensed NYC sightseeing guide. She is the author of Walking Brooklyn.
ShortDesc: Get to know the two historic yet up-and-coming neighborhoods at the cultural heart of Brooklyn.
Title: Walking Brooklyn: Crown Heights & Prospect Heights

Description:
NYC’s premiere flower district is home to many interior and window display designers.

Explore wholesale flower, plant and supply shops along 28th street with George Vallo, owner of Portafioriny, a floral design studio. Opportunities to purchase items will be made available throughout the tour.
ShortDesc: NYC’s premiere flower district is home to many interior and window display designers.
Title: NYC Flower Market

Description:
From its roots as an independent city to its current status as the hippest place on earth, Williamsburg has a rich heritage of multiculturalism, landmark architecture and prominent industry.

Visit sites associated with the civic, commercial, religious and artistic life of Williamsburg now and in the past, witness the ongoing waterfront redevelopment, and get up close to one of NYC’s great bridges.

 

Brief Bio

Adrienne Onofri is a journalist and licensed NYC sightseeing guide. She is the author of Walking Brooklyn.
ShortDesc: From its roots as an independent city to its current status as the hippest place on earth, Williamsburg has a rich heritage of multiculturalism, landmark architecture and prominent industry.
Title: Walking Brooklyn: Williamsburg
